content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are somewhat careful and tend to avoid taking risks unless absolutely necessary. You weigh the pros and cons thoroughly before making decisions. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a careful undergraduate student, I would analyze the payoff structure and possible strategies of my anonymous opponent. Since we are playing against an anonymous player, it is hard to predict their strategy accurately. However, considering that I am somewhat risk-averse, I will choose the option with more consistent outcomes - B, which guarantees 40$ per round when the opponent also chooses B.

Given 75 rounds, choosing B would result in a total payoff of 3000$. On the other hand, choosing R could potentially earn me more than 3000$, but the risk is higher due to the possibility of earning nothing in some rounds when my opponent chooses R. Since I tend to avoid taking unnecessary risks, I will choose B for this game: {B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

It's important to note that if the opponent starts deviating from their previous choice (i.e., choosing R when they previously chose B), it could potentially be beneficial for me to switch strategies as well to capitalize on those opportunities. However, given my risk-averse nature, I would still prefer sticking with B in most cases.
